Man, this is a tough one. There is a lot to love here for Elden Ring fans, but I'd say the game misses it's mark overall.

Obviously, you've got the same fantastic Elden Ring combat. Plenty of familiar bosses are here, and in particular there are a few from the Dark Souls franchise which I thought was an awesome addition. Characters are extremely diverse and allow you to approach your favorite play-styles in unique ways when incorporating the special characters abilities. There is a character here for most everyone, and its fun to switch it up and improve at all of them. Nightlords are, for the most part, really fun and engaging fights that demand your attention and teamwork (there are some stinkers though, you know the ones). Leveling system being more streamlined compliments the new faster-paced gamplay nicely. And skins are pretty cool overall too. 

BUT.....there is not even close to enough variation in content here. Build variety is technically there but so many effects and passives are just boring and enhance your character in the most minuscule ways. Relics are just like the effects; there are a FEW interesting ones but by and large they are boring and unneeded for success in the game. Honestly, by the time you have beaten all the Nightlords for the first time, you will have seen basically the entire game. The amount of map seeds in the game is a JOKE, and the boss pool is laughably small considering all the bosses they could have used but didn't. The 'rare' occurrences in the game are quite frankly TOO rare, to the point where you almost never see them in any given session. Then, instead of maybe adding more stuff to the game, they made Deep of Night mode instead, which is an absolute grind-a-thon that gets unendingly frustrating even as early as Depth 2.

We're SOOOO close guys! This is a fun and engaging Elden Ring spin-off, but it is BEGGING for more variety. I have had fun with it, enough for me to still leave a positive review, but saying I recommend it would be a huge overstatement. Give it some time to cook if you are on the fence, hopefully the upcoming DLC will fix some of these problems.

There's a lot to talk about with this game, but I'll try to keep it short. I did not expect to enjoy this game as much as I did when I first found out about it. If you have friends who are familiar with and enjoy the combat mechanics of the Souls games then I think this is a no-brainer purchase. It's addictive. You'll have a great time together. It's a distilled Souls multiplayer experience. There's a lot to love... but also plenty to hate, particularly when you've delved into the Deep of Night, which can be extremely punishing. Sometimes you have a great run and it feels fantastic to utterly obliterate the foe, while other times your great run meant nothing and you get destroyed at the end. Sometimes you have a terrible run that ends exactly how you think it will, but other times you somehow manage to overcome everything despite it all, which feels amazing. I think the core of it, this balance between luck and ability, can be very satisfying. 

The combat, by virtue of being split between a variety of unique characters with special abilities, feels like an evolutionary step forward for the Souls games. It's the main focus and the highlight. Each Nightfarer feels different and comes with a number of benefits and drawbacks. Unfortunately, while all characters are viable, some require significantly more effort or good luck than others to stand on equal ground. They can all be modified with relics, which are obtained by completing expeditions, win or lose, and purchased with currency gained the same way. They provide various stat boosts or enhancements to skills and abilities. There are also relics with extra powerful effects, usually accompanied by debuffs, that are exclusive to use in the Deep of Night mode.

A run in the game begins with you selecting an expedition, determining the Night Lord boss you'll fight at the very end. You're dropped onto the map, the same one every time, but sprinkled with various interchangeable points of interest. These usually hold specific treasures and enemies, with certain types of location having different presets, such as holy or fire, which will have an effect on the enemies, weapons, and items you can obtain within. Shifting Earth events are the only real significant changes to the map, although these are random unless you spend currency gained from defeating enhanced bosses. They're very well worth it though, as completing an event usually provides some kind of huge benefit as well as a higher likelihood of finding powerful legendary weapons within the bounds of the Shifting Earth. 

An expedition is divided into three days, and as a day progresses, a damaging rain begins to fall, shrinking the area of the map you can explore without your health constantly draining and eventually instantly dying. You fight a night boss at the end of each day, drawn from a specific pool for each expedition, and then in lieu of a proper third day, you are teleported to an area where you can do a little last minute prep before fighting the final boss of the expedition. Each day is fairly strictly timed, the only real change in the duration of an expedition depending on how long it takes you to deal with the night bosses. On average I'd say a single expedition takes around 40-50 minutes, which means you're dealing with the longest runback in any FromSoft game if you're defeated by the Night Lord at the end. You can also experience various random events during a run, from another Night Lord raiding you to a crashing meteorite, which all give you different rewards.

The game provides a fair escalation in challenge. Once you've completed at least one expedition against seven of the eight expedition bosses, you can challenge their Everdark Sovereign forms, which are enhanced versions of the fight with new moves and gimmicks that get rotated out on a weekly basis. These earn you a special currency called Sovereign Sigils when beaten, in addition to the Murk currency you usually earn from a normal expedition. For when even they get too easy, you can take on the Deep of Night after defeating the final boss. All enemies, including bosses, both deal and take considerably more damage in this mode, getting progressively more powerful the greater your depth level, and certain ones on the map will also become red, which means they're even tougher than the others, but will drop red rarity weapons. These have additional passive effects, many of which are unique to this mode, in addition to negative ones. Some of these negative effects are so detrimental that an otherwise amazing weapon can be ruined by them. You still want to stack the best buffs, of course, but there's now more to consider.

However, you cannot select the Night Lord you fight at the end of a Deep of Night expedition. It's randomly selected at the beginning, and sometimes in deeper depths, they aren't revealed even then, although you can hazard a guess based on the night bosses you fight. Your map, which usually displays all the points of interest, can also be blank, only filling in with places you personally visit, which makes planning a route, one of the key aspects of the game, much more difficult. As well, you won't know if you're fighting the normal or Everdark version of the Night Lord until you're actually in combat with them, and given how different some of the bosses are between versions, this can really screw you over in terms of what to prep for, without even considering just how much more difficult some of these fights are with just the enhanced HP and damage they receive. Some of these bosses can be very frustrating in this mode. Therein lies the challenge, I suppose. 

The game is hampered a bit by lack of randomness. For example, you might notice that the merchants you can buy things from during a run, while selling different collections of weapons, will provide the same ones with the same passives each time. Only certain night bosses will appear during the expedition for each Night Lord. Particular events can only happen during specific expeditions, like fighting a secondary night boss, which would be much more fun and interesting if it could happen during any run. I think the only thing that might be properly random is what weapons drop and the combination of skills and passives they can possess, which is unfortunate. 

All that being said, I think this game is great. I've gotten enough out of this that I can wholeheartedly say it was well worth the money. If it received more love and attention, it could be even greater. We already have a few familiar faces from Dark Souls thrown in as night bosses, why not toss in a few more? Mix them into the boss pools, which could be enlarged or removed completely so there's more variety for each expedition. Maybe some of the bosses that only appear at the end of the night could show up on the map and vice versa. Stuff could be added in from Shadow of the Erdtree, which it does seem like we're getting soon with The Forsaken Hollows. A few more playable characters might be nice... Original weapons and enemies... They could easily continue adding content to this. I hope that they do!

Elden Ring: Nightreign - A stellar, shadow-drenched expansion

Elden Ring: Nightreign isn't just DLC; it‚Äôs a full-scale descent into a hauntingly beautiful and brutally refined version of the Lands Between we thought we knew. FromSoftware has done it again, but with a focused intensity that feels both familiar and thrillingly new.

The Good:

The Realm of Night: This new region is a masterclass in atmospheric design. Cloaked in perpetual twilight, it trades the base game's golden vistas for muted blues, deep purples, and unsettling bioluminescence. The visual storytelling is impeccable.

Bosses That Will Break You (In The Best Way): The new roster of enemies and bosses is exceptional. They are fast, ferocious, and demand you re-learn their intricate, punishing dance. The victories here feel earned like nowhere else.

Meaningful Progression: The new weapons, spells, and gear aren't just side-grades. They introduce wildly unique playstyles and powerful effects that feel impactful enough to rebuild your character around. The power fantasy is real.

Lore That Pulls You Deeper: For Tarnished hungry for answers and new mysteries, Nightreign delivers. It expands the mythos in satisfying and terrifying ways, adding crucial depth to key figures and the world's history.

The Not-So-Good:

Punishing Even by FromSoft Standards: The initial difficulty spike is severe. Veteran players will be challenged, but newcomers or those who found the base game tough might hit a wall early on.

The Shadow Can Feel Oppressive: The consistently dark palette, while stunning, can sometimes make navigation and spotting secrets more taxing on the eyes over long sessions.

A Few Recycled Ideas: A handful of lesser enemies feel like reskins from the base game, which slightly breaks immersion in this otherwise pristine new world.

Verdict:
Elden Ring: Nightreign is an essential pilgrimage for any Lord or Lady. It captures the original's magic of discovery and conquest while carving its own identity in the pantheon of great expansions. It's challenging, breathtaking, and deeply rewarding‚Äîa must-play for anyone who heeded the call of the Elden Ring.

My experience with Nightreign is the kind of game that leaves you feeling mixed at first, then you learn to like it, and finally you hate it.

Starting with the positives, transforming Elden Ring into a roguelike style is an interesting gamble, and it's mostly a successful one. You learn to think about a plan of action, where to go next, churches? castle? great ennemy? You learn to improvise if a Night Lord comes and messes with you during the day, and if, like me, boss fights are what you love about Souls games, the game puts a big emphasis on them. The characters' stories are decent, and each one has an artistic direction that sets them apart from the others, just like the Night Lords, for that matter. And some OST are gorgeous too, hi Caligo and Heolstor !

So why am I giving it a negative rating? Because Nightreign is a fun game, but it has some unbearable flaws. I classify them into two categories: the ones from the basic content and the ones from the additional content, which are even worse and amplify the former's even more.

I'll be brief with the first case: servers that literally cause the game to bug, 6 seconds of latency because my session wants to run on a server in Asia, I know its Peer 2 Peer but holy ****, some map seeds are much more advantageous than others, so your runs can heavily rely on RNG. And meeting the same bosses over and over again can be a bit repetitive, most players expected more variety of bosses from all soulsgame.

But the RNG/Servers flaws, are somewhat manageable for an experienced Nightreign player. Until these are made three times more unpleasant by the other category of problems in this game: the flaws in the additional content.

The added content concerns the Everdarks and the Deep of Night:

The Everdark content is a Hardcore mode of nightlords : some offers a very balanced challenge like Adel or Fulghor. But some of them feel sluggish and lazy, like Caligo, and even worse, some are VERY POORLY designed, like Libra. You just need to look at his wiki page to see what an abomination this boss can be and how he inflicts Madness in real life.

But the biggest flaw in the game right now is its ‚ÄúDeep of Night‚Äù mode.

A ranking system that is becoming increasingly difficult in the most sloppy and unfair way possible. There are 5 levels, each requiring a certain number of points to reach that you gain by winning, and lose by getting defeated, and the Night Lord is chosen randomly for each run. The difficulty is that now, enemies have more health and damage (creative...), but ALSO, the higher you climb in level and therefore in difficulty, the more points you lose when you lose a game. You can win against 3 Everdarks at level 4 or 5, but be aware that A SINGLE DEFEAT will take away the equivalent of THREE VICTORIES. So in a game mode where almost everything kills you in one hit, you need to have a win rate of over 75% to progress. Now take all the flaws I've mentioned, the connection issues, the poorly balanced Everdarks that have a chance of appearing, the runs where a single bad teammate can cost you a game, and the ranking system becomes more frustrating than League of Legends (congratulations on that).

But do you win something for all that effort? No. no skins, no new characters, no skills. Oh yes, if you reach DEPTH 5 WITH 9999 POINTS you get a tiny little glowing banner. Might as well climb the Mount Everest in exchange for a biscuit.

A simple rebalancing of the additional content and dedicated servers (this is FromSoftware, so I doubt it) would massively improve the game. But until that happens, the negative aspects of the game overshadow the positive ones after you've completed the basic content (about fifteen hours).

My advice is to buy the game on sale. Forty bucks seems a little too much, and my opinion will remain negative until the game is properly rebalanced. And of course like the pigeon that I am, I will buy the DLC.
